The State Administrator shall establish a Problem Resolution Office where officers can investigate taxpayer complaints and stop collection activities if they are likely not compliant with the law. Only the highest official in the relevant taxing authority can reverse this decision with clear evidence, and officers cannot be penalized for their actions. The Problem Resolution Officers can issue administrative injunctions based on clear evidence, which cannot be overturned by anyone else. Officers will not face consequences unless they repeatedly issue unreasonable injunctions. The State Administrators and taxpayers still have the right to pursue legal remedies in court. "SEC. 53. JURISDICTION AND INTERSTATE ALLOCATION." The Secretary will establish an Office of Revenue Allocation to resolve disputes among states regarding the destination of taxable property and services for revenue allocation from taxes imposed by this subtitle. The Office of Revenue Allocation will arbitrate disputes among states regarding the destination of taxable property for revenue allocation. The Administrator's determination can be reviewed in federal court with the standard of review being abuse of discretion. Tangible personal property's destination is the state where it was first delivered to the purchaser. The destination of taxable property for revenue allocation disputes will be arbitrated by the Office of Revenue Allocation, with the standard of review being abuse of discretion. Tangible personal property's destination is the state where it was first delivered to the purchaser, while real property's destination is the state where the property is located, and other property's destination is the purchaser's residence. The destination of real property or rents/leaseholds on real property is the state where the property is located. Other property's destination is the purchaser's residence. Services' destination is the state where they are used, consumed, or enjoyed, with telecommunications services being based on the residence of the user. Allocation of service invoices for services involving multiple jurisdictions is based on time. Telecommunications services are allocated based on the purchaser's residence, including telephone, telegraph, cable television, satellite, and computer services. Domestic transportation services are allocated based on the final destination of the trip within the United States. For domestic transportation services within the United States, the destination is the final destination of the trip. For international transportation services, 50 percent of the service amount is attributed to the United States destination or origin. Financial intermediation services are also included in the allocation process. The destination of financial intermediation services is the residence of the purchase. A State Tax Administrator has jurisdiction over gross payments with a destination within their state. This jurisdiction is not exclusive. Rents and royalties for the lease of tangible property are also covered. The State Tax Administrator has jurisdiction over gross payments with a destination within their state, which is not exclusive. Rents and royalties for the lease of tangible property are determined by the location of the property. Rent and lease payments for vehicles depend on the term length and the location where the vehicle was originally delivered to the lessee. For rentals and leases of vehicles, the location for vehicles shall be the original delivery location for rentals of one month or less, and the residence of the lessee for rentals of more than one month. SEC. 54. Tax to be stated and charged separately. For each purchase of taxable property or services subject to a sales tax, the vendor must separately charge the tax from the purchase price and provide a receipt to the purchaser. The receipt should include the price exclusive of tax, the amount of tax paid, the price inclusive of tax, and the tax rate. The vendor must provide a receipt for taxable property or services sold, including the price exclusive of tax, amount of tax paid, price inclusive of tax, tax rate, date of sale, vendor's name, and registration number. Sales by vending machines are exempt from these requirements. The vending machine exception exempts sales from the requirements of providing a receipt for taxable property or services. Vending machines must dispense taxable property for coins or bills up to twenty dollars and sell items not exceeding ten dollars per unit in price. The State Administrator or Secretary can enter installment agreements with taxpayers to facilitate tax collection. Agreements remain valid unless inaccurate information is provided. The Secretary and State Administrator have the authority to compromise on alleged amounts due. SEC. 56. ACCOUNTING. Vendors and persons must remit taxes based on when payment is received. An election can be made to use the accrual method for reporting transactions. For bad debts under the accrual method, refer to section 11(g). SEC. 57. HOBBY ACTIVITIES. SEC. 57. HOBBY ACTIVITIES. The exemption for non-profit trade or business is not available for taxable property or services. If gross payments exceed certain criteria in 2 of the last 4 years, the business is deemed for profit. (a) Appropriations for expenses of the Internal Revenue Service, including processing income tax returns, revenue accounting, and payroll tax data transfer, are not authorized for years after fiscal year 2001.
(b) Section 7801 is amended to include the creation of an Excise Tax Bureau and a Sales Tax Bureau within the Department of Treasury to administer excise and national sales taxes. The Department of Treasury will have an Excise Tax Bureau to administer excise taxes and a Sales Tax Bureau to handle the national sales tax in certain states. The Sales Tax Bureau will also manage other federal duties related to the national sales tax. The Office of Revenue Allocation will be within the Sales Tax Bureau to handle sales tax requirements. The Secretary of the Treasury may appoint up to 5 Assistant General Counsels without following civil service laws. Modifications to federal income tax for taxable years ending June 30, 1999, are outlined. Modifications to federal income tax for taxable years ending June 30, 1999, include reducing dollar figures by half for calendar year taxpayers and adjusting dollar figures for fiscal year taxpayers. For fiscal year taxpayers, the dollar figures in sections 1 and 11 are adjusted based on the number of months in the taxpayer's taxable year ending June 30, 1999. The Secretary is required to publish tax rate schedules accordingly. The Social Security Administration will collect payroll taxes starting January 1, 1999. This includes self-employment income taxes and employment taxes. Section 7 of the Act covers revised rules for self-employment tax. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to define 'self-employment income' as gross payments received in a calendar year from the sale of taxable property or services, minus purchases of taxable property or services, wages paid for business purposes, unused transition amounts, and undeducted negative self-employment income from prior periods. The transition amounts for self-employment income include wages paid for business purposes, unused transition amounts, and undeducted negative self-employment income from prior periods. The transition amount for the ten calendar years starting in 1999 is calculated based on the unrecovered basis amount as of December 31, 1998. The unrecovered basis amount for self-employment income is calculated by dividing the basis amount as of December 31, 1998 by ten. This amount pertains to prior law section 167 property and inventory held as of the end of 1998. Conforming amendments are made to subsections 1402(b) and 1402(c), with subsections 1402(d) et seq. being renumbered as subsections 1402(b) et seq. SEC. 8. SOCIAL SECURITY BENEFITS INDEXED ON SALES TAX INCLUSIVE BASIS. The text chunk discusses the amendment of the Consumer Price Index increase percentage calculation for Social Security benefits under the Social Security Act. The text chunk discusses the calculation of the Consumer Price Index increase percentage for Social Security benefits under the Social Security Act, based on the Department of Labor's index for the most recent prior calendar quarter. The term 'CPI increase percentage' in the Social Security Act refers to the percentage by which the Consumer Price Index for a quarter exceeds the index for the most recent prior quarter. The national sales tax factor is determined by the sales tax rate divided by one minus the sales tax rate, and it must exceed the index for the most recent prior calendar quarter or cost-of-living computation quarter. SEC. 9. COMPENSATING PAYMENTS TO CERTAIN PERSONS ON FIXED INCOME. Compensating payments are provided to eligible persons who comply with the application requirements. The payment is calculated based on the qualified fixed income payment amount and the excess inflation rate. An eligible person is defined as someone receiving Social Security benefits and qualified fixed income payments. An eligible person, defined as someone receiving Social Security benefits and qualified fixed income payments, is entitled to compensating payments based on the qualified fixed income payment amount. Qualified fixed income payments are received by beneficiaries under defined benefit plans or annuitants under annuity contracts. Payments under annuity contracts entered into after June 30, 1999, are not considered qualified fixed income payments if they vary with investment performance, interest rates, or inflation. Additionally, payments from defined benefit plans to beneficiaries who were participants in the plan are not qualified fixed income payments. The qualified fixed income payment amount is \1/12\ of qualified fixed income payments that an eligible person is entitled to receive during the calendar year subsequent to the year for which the compensating payment is made. The qualified fixed income payment amount is \1/12\ of qualified fixed income payments that an eligible person is entitled to receive during the subsequent calendar year, not exceeding $5,000. The excess inflation rate is the difference between the consumer price index (all urban) during the 18-month period ending December 31, 2000, and the projected increase in the consumer price index. The excess inflation rate is determined by comparing the consumer price index (all urban) over an 18-month period ending December 31, 2000, with the projected increase in the consumer price index. To receive compensating payments, eligible individuals must apply as required by the Secretary of Health and Human Services. To receive compensating payments, eligible individuals must apply as required by the Secretary of Health and Human Services. The compensating payment will be received with Social Security benefits, funded from the general fund. The Secretary may require insurers to provide documentation for the application process. The Secretary of Health and Human Services may require insurers and defined benefit plan sponsors to issue statements to annuitants or plan participants for qualified fixed income payment amounts. The compensating payment, funded from the general fund, may be included in one check. SEC. 10 amends Section 6621 of the Internal Revenue Code by adjusting interest rates. SEC. 11 states that a supermajority is required to raise the rate. SEC. 11 requires a supermajority vote in the House of Representatives or the Senate to consider any bill that increases federal sales tax rates or reduces federal revenues through exemptions or benefits. The waiver or suspension of this requirement can only be done with a two-thirds affirmative vote.
